title: Lactational Mastitis with Abscess Formation
setup_script: A 28-year-old woman who is breastfeeding her newborn develops fever, breast pain, and swelling in the right breast. On exam, there is a 3 cm tender, fluctuant mass with erythema.

dynamic_flow.trigger: Obtain history of breastfeeding technique, milk stasis, and systemic symptoms; assess for risk factors like nipple trauma.
Perform physical exam noting localized warmth, tenderness, and fluctuance; check axillary nodes.
Diagnose mastitis versus abscess; order breast ultrasound to confirm abscess and guide drainage.
Initiate broad-spectrum antibiotics covering Staphylococcus aureus and MRSA (e.g., dicloxacillin or clindamycin).
Encourage continued breastfeeding or pumping to facilitate drainage unless abscess is large and painful.
Plan ultrasound-guided needle aspiration of abscess; send fluid for culture and sensitivity.
If abscess fails to resolve or recurs, perform incision and drainage under local anesthesia; pack cavity and instruct on wound care.
Monitor response to therapy; repeat aspiration if necessary; adjust antibiotics based on culture results.
Educate patient on proper breastfeeding technique, frequent feeding, and nipple care to prevent recurrence.
Discuss potential need for lactation consultant and support.
If severe or systemic illness persists, consider hospitalization for IV antibiotics and surgical drainage.
Plan follow-up to ensure resolution and evaluate for underlying pathology if abscess recurs (e.g., inflammatory cancer).

critical_decision_points: Differentiating mastitis from abscess and using ultrasound for diagnosis.
Appropriate antibiotic selection and continued breastfeeding advice.
Technique for aspiration versus incision and drainage and timing.
Monitoring for resolution and adjusting therapy based on cultures.
Education on breastfeeding practices and prevention of recurrence.
